title: Can higher education ensure employment? - Quora

response.answer_text: The answer is somewhat related to both internal drive, determination and passion. Can a higher education open doors absolutely, from someone who achieved a Bachelors Degree latter in life, I wish I had done it right out of High School. I ran into a lot of cases where I was told in job interviews that a Bachelors degree was required at a minimum. So promise a good job, not necessarily but it may get you to an interview someone without was not invited to. Now we have all heard of the Tech Boom where guys like Michael Dell, Bill Gates and Mark Zuckerberg dropped out of college and now look at them - the you can too mentality that I believed fueled the idea that you don’t need a college degree. According to Bill Gates from his Blog: “Although I dropped out of college and got lucky pursuing a career in software, getting a degree is a much surer path to success,” Entrepreneurs who dropped out of college: Michael Dell, Dell founder, dropped out at 19Steve Jobs, Apple founder, dropped out at 19Julian Assange, Wikileaks founder, dropped out at 19Bill Gates, Microsoft founder, dropped out at 20Evan Williams, Twitter co-founder, dropped out at 20Mark Zuckerberg, Facebook founder, dropped out at 20Larry Ellison, Oracle founder, dropped out at 20Jan Koum, WhatsApp founder, dropped out at 21Travis Kalanick, Uber founder, dropped out at 21John Mackey, Whole Foods founder, dropped out at 22I worked at Dell Computer for 12 years and Michael Dell did not finish college but built a great company. I thought he would be open to people that also did not finish college but had a lot to contribute. He attended some of my customer briefings. Exactly the opposite, he stated more than once while I was there he would never hire someone for an important role within company that did not have a degree. He knew there was a lot he did not know in the beginning. I relate it to “polish” those around with degrees just had more exposure and the fine edges that others who did good work but did not have a degree did not posses in their work. In a development role it was easy to see those who spent a lot of time on a single discipline but did not get the exposure to many different areas from College. They did what they knew not necessarily what best fit the job. They also did not get promoted very far, they were seen as less capable (not because of a lack of a degree although in some cases but mostly capabilities). The truth is a degree paves to road to make success easier to achieve. Now the determination and passion part. If you have enough determination you can achieve anything. However for some the fire begins to smolder at times for lack of direction which is more of a product from lack of knowledge than anything else. You can read about those who dropped out of college that are household names at: Famous Entrepreneurs Who Dropped Out Of College - Infographic Just keep in mind the world has approximately 7.4 billion people, with 318 million in the US. A degree will separate you from a lot of those who don’t in just knowledge and capabilities. You have a much better chance of success. “Don’t think about the promise of a good job” but the enabling to find a great job. No guarantees in life, you have to work for it and earn it. I have met a lot of people who say they have a degree and cant find a job. I believe they have never applied themselves but expected a job upon graduation. You should be thinking about what you want to do all through college researching and looking for internships etc. If you can’t find a job you aren’t applying yourself. If you are getting job interviews with a degree just keep in mind there are a lot who aren’t even getting the interview without a degree.

American schoolkids contemplating whether to tackle colossal understudy advances are always informed that school is the portal to the white collar class. In all actuality more nuanced, as Barack Obama indicated when he said in January that "people can make significantly more" by taking in an exchange "than they may with a workmanship history degree". A furious workmanship history educator constrained him to apologize, however he was correct. School graduates matured 25 to 32 who are working all day win about $17,500 more every year than their associates who have just a secondary school confirmation, as indicated by the Pew Research Center, a research organization. Be that as it may, not all degrees are similarly helpful. What's more, given the amount they cost—a private four-year degree can set you back as much as $60,000 a year—numerous understudies wind up more terrible off than if they had begun working at 18.

Nope, it promises that it will attempt to teach you about the world. This often results in you having skills that will assist you in finding a good job, as by learning about the world you can often perform tasks at a higher degree of competency than if you didn’t learn. In addition, a credential can act as a signal to others that you have some minimum level of competence and the higher the credential the higher that minimum is. But, if you want a promise of a good job, education is not the path. Political and economic structures determine the odds of finding a good job. To use an extreme, right now a degree in computer science is highly employable, but it would have been practically useless 2000 years ago. A match between your skills and the skills that are in demand is what promises you a good job.

Not necessarily.  If a person is willing to work, let him/her be educated or not, they are bound to get employment.  There is always work for hard workers.   Then, why do people get educated?  When a person becomes choosy for a particular type of job, then he/she requires understanding of the job and for this purpose, they educate themselves.  If a person goes for higher education, they may be wanting a particular type of job and that may or may not be available at that point of time.   For this reason, after basic education, many will go for a job, get experience and then study further so that they get best out of such education.

No, actually it might even hurt your job finding. I have a Master in Education, and schools rather take a Post Grad. Diploma of Education since that is more practical ande Masters are too theoretical(With the extra 3 months in practice, come on). Turned down by a dozen of schools becuase of this. However, the higher your education, the wider range your choice of jobs becomes. Meaning you have higher possibility in getting a better job, especially after you have been working for quite some time and gained certain experience.

Absolutely not! Statistics show it is just as easy for someone who is a non- college graduate to get a higher paid job by working up the ranks of the company. Even better a non-college grad does not accumulate all of the worthless debt! Truthfully if you want the highest paying income without all the working up the corporate ladder non-sense, I would recommend you becoming a entrepreneur. There is no cap to how much you can make… and you are able to have your own time and not build someone else’s dream!

I guess it depends on your field. It helps in engineering although most (big) companies will pay for you to go to school while you work. Some small companies will and some will pay for your PE because it helps them when you can sign off designs. If you are in engineering or science it is probably best to wait till your senior year. Take some interviews and talk to some grad schools. I had offers either way but I was tired of Top Ramen so I took a job. I went back for my MS 12 years later on a company fellowship. It was a very good deal. Plus I was able to tailor my program to my job.

I’m in the UK. I have a BSc and two MPhils (UK mini-PhDs) in medically related subjects. I’m stuck in fixed-term administrative jobs in our health service that pay a little over £19000 per year, and I’m too broke to do a long distance move to get something better. So, no. On the other hand, if you study a scientific subject and are better at running your life than I’ve been, you’ll almost certainly do better than this. Good luck!

It does not ensure employment. But it is easy to gain job with a graduation and good skill. But the Graduate unemployment rates have spiraled across the world. So the marks obtained and skill is also important with the graduation certificate. Nowadays the competition is more in the job field. So it is very tough to get a good job. So many will go for a job, and get experience and then study further so that they get best out of such education.

Getting a good job in the US requires a marketable skill and a credential. Unfortunately many parents and students ASSUME “credential” means a four year degree. There are two applicants with bachelor’s degrees for every suitable job for graduates. It’s a completion, and half the competitors are going to lose. There are well paying jobs available. They just require the RIGHT “post-secondary” education. And, unfortunately, many of those jobs are not considered to be “cool.”

Higher education holds the promise of obtaining better, more meaningful, higher waged employment if you can utilise the knowledge and skills acquired during your education. This does not automatically equate to “I have a degree wheres my paycheck” however.
Higher education can ensure that you understand and then write eloquently about your unemployment.  Higher ed cannot really ensure anything, but it can elucidate most everything.
Ensure? No. But it sure as heck helps a lot.

Not necessarily - but it opens up more options. Too many people are attending universities and getting bullshit degrees, so a degree doesn’t mean much anymore, sadly. Depends on what you call a good job, too. You better start by defining that first.
